metadata.title: All Names are not Treated Equally | by Quinn Keck | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: All Names are not Treated Equally
metadata.description: As machine learning becomes increasingly popular, more and more tasks are being automated. While this can have many positive benefits, like freeing up humans’ time to do more challenging tasks, there…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: Google’s facial recognition algorithm labeled black people as gorillas
mishap with Amazon’s resume recommendation system
Semantics derived automatically from language corpora contain human-like biases
an example barber resume on job hero

all_paragraphs: As machine learning becomes increasingly popular, more and more tasks are being automated. While this can have many positive benefits, like freeing up humans’ time to do more challenging tasks, there can be unintended consequences.

Any machine algorithm is trained using data humans created that may convey messages and ideas the people who generated the data or who are building the model would not intend or want. There are numerous examples of models that contain unintended bias against certain groups of people. You may have heard about Google’s facial recognition algorithm labeled black people as gorillas or the more recent mishap with Amazon’s resume recommendation system where the algorithm taught itself that male candidates were preferable and penalized resumes containing the word “women” that could be found in phrases such as “Women’s Golf Team Captain.”

Despite the widespread use of these kinds of algorithms, how to address the bias they contain is very much an open and unsolved problem. It is also a nuanced problem, as there is no clear cut mathematical metric of how much bias an algorithm has. There is also not a set in stone definition of bias; while I certainly believe and fight for the idea that a woman is as equally qualified as anyone for any job at Amazon, there are people in the world who don’t believe in gender equality. Nonetheless, there is an overwhelming amount of real-world examples of how bias in machine learning algorithms are discriminating against people and reinforcing injustices in our society.

Researchers are actively investigating bias in machine learning algorithms, and I encourage you to check out their work, links to which I’ve included at the end of this article. To take a stab at exploring how bias is impacting resume recommendation systems, I conducted some experiments of my own. These are very much a start that will hopefully spur more questions and research, not a solution to this very complex problem.

When explaining my process, I’m going to assume you have an understanding of machine learning, word embeddings, and natural language processing. Word embeddings were first made popular with Google’s Word2Vec algorithm, but Stanford’s glove embeddings have also risen in popularity. For a good overview of Word2Vec check out Zafar Ali’s tutorial and for an overview of Glove check out Sciforce’s article and for more details on doc2vec please check out Gidi Shperber’s introduction to doc2vec. I’ll give a brief overview of how word embeddings can be used in recommendation systems, then delve into my experiment, results, and next steps.

Instead of only comparing word vectors to one another, one can employ a variety of techniques to compare documents using the word embeddings of the words in each document. In the case of my experiments, these documents were a Google job posting and different resumes, but a document could be any kind of text data. Instead of comparing vectors that represent single words, I created vector representations of documents and their distance in vector space. The documents with vector representations closest to each other in vector space would be considered most similar to one another and recommended.

In this experiment, I calculated the vector representation (a centroid) of a document by removing stop words and then taking an average of vectors of all the remaining words in that document. After calculating the document centroid for my sample job posting and all the resumes I was testing, I compared both the Euclidean and cosine distance between the job postings centroid and each test resume’s centroid to rank the resumes. Generally, resume recommendation systems would use more than just averaging resume centroids to make recommendations, so please bear in mind a system in production would have more algorithms and steps involved, but this experiment can still provide insights.

There are no truly neutral choices in this kind of subjective domain, and I am inherently incorporating my own beliefs into how I set up and ran this experiment. It’s important for researchers like me to not only examine their own bias but also to look to other research and collaborate with others to mitigate bias.

No name or set of names can truly represent any group of people. Many people have names that do not reflect their self-identified race or gender. Gender is also not a binary construct, though for the purposes of this experiment I only compare masculine and feminine names. I chose to use the set of names that Aylin Caliskan, Joanna J. Bryson, and Arvind Narayanan used in their paper Semantics derived automatically from language corpora contain human-like biases. I don’t feel qualified to pick names myself that would even begin to be representative of a group of people I don’t belong to, nor will there ever be a set of names that can fully represent any group. I used the African American and European names they used and further divided them into gendered groups. I compared eight sets of resumes with the following sets of names:
● Female Names (combining Female European American Names and Female African American Names)
● Male Names (combining Male European American Names and Male African American Names)

I’m conducting this research in American English, but these kinds of investigations should be happening in all languages with native speakers leading the research. I chose a Google software engineering job posting and to create software engineering resumes because software engineering is a widely recognized, high paying field that is currently male-dominated. Google is a leader in the field and is a highly sought-after employer, so seemed like a reasonable choice of company to use a job posting from. I also chose software engineering because I felt that by drawing on my domain expertise from my data science studies and work experience I could craft a reasonable entry-level resume. In future experiments, it would be useful to look at job postings from different companies and in different fields.

To draft my generic entry-level software engineering resume, I combined text from indeed.com’s, Carnegie Mellon’s computer science department, and monster.com’s sample software engineering resumes. Each resume included an education section, one year of related work experience, one year of unrelated work experience, and a software engineering projects section. For the unrelated work experience, I used text from an example barber resume on job hero.
To calculate the centroid for the Google job posting I took the following steps using 300-dimensional pre-trained glove embeddings:
To calculate a resume centroid for each group of names, I took the following steps:

When using the glove vectors, I found that resumes with male European American names were the closest when using either Euclidean or cosine distance to the Google software engineering resume. The next closest group is European American Names, followed by all-male names. I looked at the Euclidean and cosine distance, as well as how many standard deviations away each group was away from the mean distance of all groups to the job posting.

This demonstrates the unintended but nonetheless negative impact of the bias encoded in these word embeddings. While all groups are within 2 standard deviations from the mean, there is a clear pattern in the order of the groups when looking at the distributions of either Euclidean or cosine distances between groups. The group of Male European American resumes is about 3 standard deviations closer to the Google job posting than the group of Male African America Names. Both racial and gender discrimination affect how these resumes are ranked. These resumes are identical other than the name that is on them and should all be equally close to the job posting.

Currently addressing bias in word embeddings is an active area of research. Until there are more robust solutions for addressing bias, I believe anyone using recommendation systems should remove names from the resume text that is used by the system’s ranking system. Job titles and experiences that imply a candidate’s gender are also are likely to affect results but are more complicated to remove. These results are only preliminary, and these kinds of experiments should be repeated with different names, job postings, etc. A/B testing these identical resumes in a resume recommendation system that is in production would also provide valuable insights.

In a fair and just world, everyone’s resume would be equally likely to be recommended by any algorithm, regardless of their name or identity. This is only one of many cases where the bias in word embeddings and machine learning models is harmful, and in any area of research, we need all the voices and ideas we can get. I encourage you to learn more, collaborate with others, and if you are in a company using this wording embedding in any part of your recommendation system, to investigate the bias that is encoded and work to address that.

A special thanks to Rachel Thomas and James Wilson for their support in this endeavor. For more details, please check out my GitHub. I would love to hear your thoughts and suggestions as well as ideas for further research!
I invite feedback and can be reached at keck.quinn<at>gmail.com. Thanks for reading!

By William L. Hamilton, Jure Leskovec, Dan Jurafsky
Man is to Computer Programmer as Woman is to Homemaker? Debiasing Word Embeddings
By Tolga Bolukbasi, Kai-Wei Chang, James Zou, Venkatesh Saligrama, Adam Kalai
Lipstick on a Pig: Debiasing Methods Cover up Systematic Gender Biases in Word Embeddings But do not Remove Them
A Framework for Understanding Unintended Consequences of Machine Learning
Companies are on the hook if their hiring algorithms are biased
Data Statements for Natural Language Processing: Toward Mitigating System Bias and Enabling Better Science
Quinn Keck is a multidisciplinary artist, printmaker and data scientist. They hold Master’s of Data Science from the University of San Francisco.
